content.description:
Fun climbing leads to the 3rd bolt, where the main line of this route goes right using BIG reaches to good holds.

As implied by the name, there are three possible ways to climb the top of this route:

5.10c variation: Move right at the third bolt and stay right as you make your way to the anchors.

5.11b/c variation: Go left at the third bolt to climb through the vertical seam. After clipping the fourth bolt, go back right to finish on the 10c main line.

5.11d variation: Stay to the left of the fourth bolt for the most challenging finish to this climb.
content.protection: 4 bolts + 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Starts just left of Bologna Pony.

content.description:
The route starts with fun moves up the wide finger crack and arete.  After clipping the second bolt, the crux moves go up and right from the end of the crack.  If you figure out the crux don't let up, as there are several delicate slab moves that must still be overcome to gain the anchors.  A very engaging climb!

The chimney to the right of the arete is off.
content.protection:
6 bolts to 2-bolt/chain anchor.

The moves to the first bolt are a little thin, but it can be clipped before you start by using the chimney and then downclimbing . . . Also clipping the third bolt can be a bit intimidating as there isn't much of a stance for your feet (although you are hanging from the best jug imaginable).
content.location: Starts at a partially detached column about 100 yards right of Bologna Pony.

content.description: This is an interesting climb with a couple of possible variations.  If you stick to the left there is a fun roof to pull over (5.9).  Taking the right side is easier.  There is a lot of loose rock near the top.  Be careful when setting anchor or top rope that you don't knock rock down on your partner.  Lots of good places for pro.
content.protection: Anchor chains on top
content.location: This is the second set of chains to the right of Toddler.  The chains look brand new (8/2018).  You can see them from the ground.

content.description: Unsure if this has a name.  Near the top you can find a fun move if you stay to the left, probably 5.8 territory.  Staying in the crack on the right is probably easier though.
content.protection: Chains on top.
content.location: There are brand new looking chains on the cliffs just right of the anchor for Toddler.

content.description: Climb the crack that is five feet to the right of Bologna Pony.  The crack starts as fingers and goes to hands at the top. One of the better crack climbs at the Black Cliffs.
content.protection: Singles in Camalots #.3 - #2. Use the same chains as Bologna Pony.  A sling is nice at the top.
content.location: Located five feet to the right of Bologna Pony.

content.description:
A lot of people lead this as a first climb. It's an easy climb that is well protected. The crux comes at the top with a bulge.

The anchors are on the top of the block at the top of the route, and not visible until the top. Runners are needed to extend the anchors if you wish to top rope it.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains.  You will need long runners to make a good top rope setup.
content.location: At the very end of the Short Cliffs (all the way to the left).

content.description: Fun crack climb that gets exciting at the top.  Taking the trail on the left side of the cliffs will put you up top were you can set this route up TR.
content.protection: Chains on top (not visible from the ground)
content.location: Crack just to the left of Minuteman dihedral.

content.description: Begins as a great hand crack with ample feet for easy placements. The crack peters out up top and leaves a thin, slabby face to the left and a steep face with chains above to the right.
content.protection: Hand crack eats up BD ones and twos. Smaller gear up top as you can find it. The bottom of the seam has some nice places to slot some small stoppers. This make the moves to the next finger sized pro a bit more comforting.
content.location: Hand crack located a couple columns climbers left of Copperhead.

content.description: Start by face climbing up towards a high first bolt. Place a few pieces of gear in a small crack before you reach the bolt. Clip two bolts, then pull onto a ledge under the roof. Lean back and clip your last bolt at the edge of the roof. Pull the roof on huge jugs but marginal feet to another ledge with the chains.
content.protection: 3 bolts and small gear to chains. I used 0.1-0.4 C4s. Could also use nuts or other small cams.
content.location: Right side of the short cliffs. Just right of Minuteman. A small crack leads up towards a roof.  You can see the obvious bolts with the last one at the edge of the roof.  See pic.

content.description: The furthest left route at The Shorts.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains

content.description:
If a rope is already up on Spiny Trouble, this is a nifty hand (arm) crack, with plenty to work with. As a beginner, I enjoyed it! The top would be Spiny Trouble, if you use those anchors. supposedly the route has anchors clear up top, but those are likely ancient. I have no idea what the two parts combined should go at.

Edit to add (8/19/18): Someone has added shiny new hangers, with properly painted chains, to this route. There are also some anchors on top, near the path. They seemed solid, but who knows how ancient they are? They are also set very far apart.
content.protection: Eats up gear rather nicely! I tried this for a first run at placing gear, and found plenty, including nice placements for big hexes.
content.location: A short crack just to the right (upstream) from Spiny Trouble. A small bush is growing out of it (Syringa, our state flower, most likely).

content.description: Harder to protect than to climb, Safe Sex Subaru follows a thin crack and plenty of face holds. Pull over a small roof on creative feet.
content.protection: Gear to .5”
content.location: Thin crack right of Jump Chump.

content.description:
Challenging dihedral left of Jump Chump that requires some overlap with that route. Subsequent to the 2016 Epeldi guide, this route has been equipped with its own anchors.

Stemming, crimping, and liebacking on a positive but flared crack make for varied climbing that would be difficult to protect.
content.protection: There appears to be at least one bolt that has been removed and the hole glued. Presently, the route takes small traditional gear and leads to two Fixe rap rings.
content.location: Obvious dihedral just left of Jump Chump.

content.description: Thinning edges lead to a crux REACH involving a palming sloper/crimp.  Latch this rig, get your feet up, and crank!
content.protection: Bolts to a 2BA.
content.location: (Edit) Third farthest left sport route at the Short Cliffs.

content.description: Stem up a dihedral to a boulder problem above the 2nd bolt. Use some very small foot holds and lots of friction to set yourself up for a large move out right, clip the 3rd bolt and get creative pulling the roof. Get on it!
content.protection:
3 bolts + anchors

Despite only having 3 bolts, the difficult portion of this route is at the top so I consider it very safe (for the Black Cliffs)
content.location: The first bolted line right of Bologna Pony. Dihedral to an obvious roof.

content.description:
A fun dihedral with sparse pro leads to the first of two roof cruxes. The first roof is easier than the second but is mentally challenging since you’re pulling on a huge, loose block.

Be advised—this may hold; it may not.

The second roof goes on big holds and requires creative footwork and long reaches.
content.protection: Small stoppers and cams to 1”.
content.location: Obvious dihedral ten feet right of Safe Sex Subaru.

content.description: A fun crack with a tricky crux going over a bulge.  Get the beta right and it's not that hard, but if not it will feel harder than the grade indicates.
content.protection: Good but small gear the whole way.  2 bolt anchor.
content.location: A few feet left of Basic Training

content.description: The crux is near the middle of the climb, and the ascent is a bit precarious for the next several feet.
content.protection: Four bolts to chains. The bolts are in a nearly straight line, the chains are to the left. It is very difficult to safely set up a toprope.
content.location: Starting at the left side of the Short Cliffs (from the bottom), the Mystery Route is about two thirds of the way to the right side. The identifying feature is the anchors being a jump to the left of the bolt line.

content.description: Climb up a dark dihedral until you reach a bulge.  Work up a solid crack and pull over the bulge on great, juggy holds.  This is a great climb! Don't miss it.
content.protection: Pro to rap bolts.  Has a fixed, yellow cam about 3/4 of the way up that you can easily see from the ground.
content.location: The far Right side of the Short Cliff.  Climb a black dihedral just left of a roof.  The roof has a sport route with 3 bolts, called Swimming in Ignorance, leading into the middle of it.  Look for the rap bolts at the top of this climb and the fixed, yellow cam.

content.description: Fun little climb.  Starts off working up a nice crack, fairly easy.  Gets harder as you go.
content.protection: There are anchor chains at the top.  Like most Short Cliff routes you can hike up to the top and set this up as a TR.
content.location: This is just to the right of Bag of Stems.  The crack is well marked with chalk from people working their way up.

climbs.name: Locker-box
climbs.fa: FKA May 2019, Michael Abend and Abe R

content.description:
Face climbing for the first half to a fun bulging hand crack.

If anyone has info on prior assents let me know.
content.protection: Nuts in the thin seam. Some more nuts in the bigger crack.
content.location: Thin seam immediately left of Neophyte Flight. Use the Neophyte Flight anchors.

content.description: Fun route with a committing feel up top, good gear, just save the small cams for last!
content.protection: Anchors up top
content.location: Start right of Basic Training and climb the right arcing crack through the roof.

content.description:
Layback, stem, and chimney the bottom section. Pull a small roof with big holds and finish on easy slab.

Epeldi guide lists this route as having no anchors, but this route currently has a two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5”
content.location: Obvious dihedral with hand and finger jams left of Another Face in the Crowd.

content.description: From Boise Climbs: Dihedral to the Goodbye Mr. Purple chains
content.protection: Chains at top
content.location: Dihedral just left of Goodbye Mr. Purple

content.description: Easy, fun climbing over large blocks until 3rd bolt. At the 3rd bolt, the route earns the "jump" part of it's name. Short climbers BEWARE! Steep 8' section with thin holds, leads to a pretty good rail and then chains.
content.protection: 3 bolts and anchors at top.
content.location: Located on the left section of the Short Cliffs. The first bolt line to the right of Petty Theft.

content.description: Pretty easy to top rope this (there are rappel bolts located above the climb which can be easily accessed by a short hike up the gully to the left of this route).  Fun little climb.  Start is super easy and then sustained 5.10 territory.
content.protection: Anchors at top.  Bolts on climbs on either side can be used for this route.
content.location: Literally "in between" Desperate Indulgence and Petty Theft.

content.description:
This line is not in the 4th edition of Boise Climbs. It’s very likely this has been climbed before, but I have found no information, so I’m basing the description and rating off the one time I’ve been on it.

If anyone knows of a prior ascent, please let me know who it was and what, if anything, they named this, and I will correct the details here. And if you climb this, please input your assessment of the grade.

Standard Black Cliffs face climbing on positive edges, but the difficulty here lies in protecting the route with only small gear, hence the name.

Line merges at the top and shares anchors with The Layback.
content.protection: Wired nuts and micro-cams to about .3”.
content.location: Left side of the arete next to The Layback.

content.description: A fun 5.11 for the Black Cliffs. Short dihedral leads you onto a couple bouldery face moves.
content.protection: 3 bolts to chains

content.description: Tricky moves off the deck without gear leading to solid pro about 20 feet up. Clip the fixed nut and pull the roof with some smeary feet. There are rumors that a block came off making the throw above the roof more solid and the grade soft (it was originally rated 5.11c).
content.protection: Small cams and wires, there is an old fixed nut before the roof.
content.location: Right of Copperhead.

content.description: From Boise Climbs: The intended line does not include using The Temple crack.  However, an edge at the left end of The Temple arch is considered to be on route.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains
content.location: Bolted route just to the left of The Temple.

content.description:
Follow a discontinuous seam on classic Black Cliffs edges until mid height, where the route steepens and the jams and pro get wider (fingers to a couple of hand jams) before getting quite thin again.

Small stoppers and cams from .3 to .5.

A two-foot section will take a #1 or a #2.

Rap rings at top.
content.protection:
Somewhat sparsely protected. Small wires and a few cams.

Rap rings at the top.
content.location: Route name painted in red at base. 8 feet right of Bologna Pony.

content.description: Aptly named! Easy to climb, easy to place gear, easy to practice top belay, and I was able to follow and clean with my very meager skills.
content.protection: Cams, if you want, but plenty of options to work with.
content.location: Listed in Boise Climbs, for more info.

content.description: Crack to the right of Jump Chump. Easy climbing leads to a roof crack with sporty moves that can be well protected. After pulling the crux, finish at the Safe Sex Subaru anchors to the right.
content.location: Inviting crack 5 ft right of the Jump Chump bolt line.

content.description: 1st-2nd bolt, 3rd-4th bolt, palm and smear, fingers
content.protection: bolts, anchors at the top
content.location: L  of Baloney Poney

content.description: Easy crack and column climbing leads to a thoughtful crux at a slab face. Clip the lone bolt and choose your own adventure to get to the chains. Working too far left will decrease the difficulty while sticking to slab alone will make it harder.
content.protection: Gear plus one bolt at the crux before the anchors.
content.location:
Between

The Pink Panther

(left) and

Tijuana T

(right)

content.description: Climb the corner and finger crack to the large ledge at mid-route.  A series of positive but well spaced edges will take you the rest of the way to the anchors.
content.protection: A finger sized piece or two to get you to the top of the ledge at midheight, and then a #0 TCU or equivalent for the horizontal 8 feet above the ledge. From there you have 2 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: 50 feet left of Bologna Pony.  The name of the route is spray-painted at its base.

climbs.name: Coupe de Ville
climbs.fa: Curtis Olsen, Al Botticelli, Dwight Allen, 1976

content.description: Fun route.  Good holds at the beginning.  Gets harder as you go.  Crux is near the top.  Thin cracks to climb over a shelf.  Big holds above the shelf.  Book rates this as 5.8 but feels more like 5.9 around the crux.  You can hike around to the top and set this up as top rope.
content.protection: Anchors at top (2 Bolts w/ chains)
content.location: Just to the right of Swimmin' in Ignorance.

content.description:
This is an excellent crack climb with great pro!

Start in a dihedral with a finger crack in the back.  enjoy great fingers and stemming, until the crack widens to perfect hands under a roof.  Pull the roof using finger locks and small edges for feet, and finish up an easier hand size crack to the anchors
content.protection: Gear from fingers to #2 camalot size.  Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Towards the right end of the Short Cliffs.  Look for a double dihedral capped by a roof about 30 feet up, about 50 feet right of Unknown Leon.

content.description: Cruiser crack/stem line that protects well (eats up mid-size nuts). Traverse to the right across a ramp atop the main pillar at the top of the climb to reach the anchors shared with the two lines to the right of this.
content.protection: Chains on top.
content.location: Just to the left of Aunt Fannie, use the same chains up top. Route name is painted at the base of the climb.

content.description: Climb Bologna Pony, but stay to the right of the last bolts to climb the thin face on some very small crimps to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains or walk-off
content.location: Starts in the same place (and shares all the same bolts) as Bologna Pony

content.description: This route is a must do.  Climb the overhanging basalt column to the chains at the top. The crux is at the top.
content.protection: Six bolts exist so bring six draws. Chains at the top or walk off.
content.location: Located on the Small Cliffs right as you top out on the trail.  I believe Bologna Pony is painted on the base of the climb.

content.description: Follow the big fat crack most of the way up. Once you finish that you'll have a large ledge to rest on before making your way up to chains to anchor on.
content.protection: A very large crack up to chains. The anchors are fairly accessible from the topside of the cliff and it makes a pretty good top rope setup.
content.location: It's the crack just to the right of Aunt Fannie. You can also find the "Buster Bronco" writing on the cliff bottom and go two cracks over to the right.

climbs.name: Basic Training
climbs.fa: Cade Lloyd, Pete Takeda, Trent Smith ~1983

content.description: Start on easy climbing up the outside of the short pillar.  Once on top of the pillar climb the crack in the dihedral to the anchors.  The crack behind the pillar starts as tips and gradually widens to fingers and then small hands.  It's a pity the crack doesn't start from the ground . . .
content.protection: Several small cams and nuts to about .5"
content.location: Starts at the base of the short pillar 20 feet right of Bologna Pony

content.description:
This is the chimney to the right of Unknown Leon. There is nowhere good to place protection until you go above and stand on a small boulder wedged in the bottom of the chimney, which is about 15 ft up. There are a couple horizontal cracks after that, and after that there is a 20 ft blank section. I climbed facing away from the cliffs, and about 5 ft below the anchor was a pocket behind me that was deep enough to stuff a C3 into.

The chimney walls are well featured and offer very secure stances. Bring a solid mental game.
content.protection: BD C4 Camalots #1 - 0.75 and a couple tip size cams. Bring 2-3 slings to extend some placements. Chains to anchors at top.
Chains up top.
content.location: Just to the right of Buster Bronco.

content.description:
Unlike most aretes at the Black Cliffs, this one has no holds! (Well, not many.)

Bring a full bag of tricks for this one.

Pinch, grab slopers, stem, drop knees, and smear your way up fun but difficult feature climbing.

Top third eases considerably with the appearance of actual holds.

The inobvious nature of this route would make it very proud onsight—I would love to see someone make the attempt!
content.protection: 4 bolts to anchors.
content.location: Bolted arete left of Unknown Leon column.

content.description: Unique route with some fun moves through the last two bolts.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains
